title: How to Make a Travel Game Kit

steps.headline: Buy or collect empty hard plastic containers or storage boxes.
steps.description: Purchase small, hard plastic storage containers at a dollar or department store. Look for containers that are at least 8.5 by 5.5 inches (22 by 14 cm) so that they’ll fit items like pencils, sticky notes, and a small notebook. Alternatively, save and clean out containers previously used for things like baby wipes. You could also use hard plastic pencil cases, which can be found where you buy school supplies, or food storage containers.

steps.headline: Print labels with names or activities for each box.
steps.description:
You can create the box using one of two methods: by game or by child. Either way, you’ll need a label for each box so that your kids know what’s inside and/or who the box belongs to. The easiest way to create a label is to print one from your computer using a word processing program. Alternatively, you could also use a label maker if you have one. For game-specific boxes, labels may include “Build Me,” “Colour Me,” or “Play Me.”
For child-specific boxes, the labels should include at least the child’s name, but could also include the name of the trip you’re taking (e.g., “Drive to Gramma & Grandpa” or “Summer Vacation to Mexico”).

steps.headline: Download travel game templates on the internet.
steps.description: Many websites have a variety of travel game templates you can download and print to use in your activity box. These games include Hangman, I Spy, Tic Tac Toe, Bingo games, Word Searches, Conversation Starters, and more. Search for “travel game templates” via a web browser and download the templates that interest you. If you’d prefer, you can use the game templates found online to create your own templates using word processing or spreadsheet software.

steps.headline: Print the travel games in colour on your printer.
steps.description: Once you’ve downloaded all the games you want, print them in colour on your printer. Alternatively, you can take them to the library to print or to a print shop. Size each game template so that it prints on half a sheet of letter-sized paper. You should be able to print 2 games per piece of paper. Some of the games rely on colour as part of the game. If you’re unable to print the game in colour, you may need to write the name of the colour on the template instead.

steps.headline: Laminate each game template for durability.
steps.description: For games that are intended to be played over and over again, you’ll want to laminate the template so that your kids can use a dry erase marker to play the game. You can use a home laminator if you have one, use a laminator at the library, or take your items to a print shop and have them laminated. As yet another alternative, you could place the paper inside a plastic sheet protector. If the sheet protector is too large for the paper, you can cut the sheet protector to an appropriate size and tape around the open edges.

steps.headline: Fill each activity-specific box with the appropriate items.
steps.description: For boxes you’ve labelled as “Build Me,” fill the box with Legos or another set of building/construction toys. For boxes labelled “Colour Me,” fill the box with colouring sheets or a small colouring book and crayons or coloured pencils. For boxes labelled “Play Me,” fill the box with the laminated travel game sheets and a couple of dry-erase markers. For easy transport put all the activity-based boxes inside a tote bag or backpack.

steps.headline: Add a variety of items to your child-specific boxes to keep each kid busy.
steps.description: Make each child’s activity/game box specific to their age. All boxes can include a notebook and writing material, a small clipboard (to create a hard surface on which to play the games), sticky notes, and dry erase markers. Select the appropriate game templates based on the abilities of your children so that each game is fun and challenging. For younger kids, you can include: pencils, crayons, stickers, Legos, and easy games like Tic Tac Toe or Hangman. For older kids, you can include: pencil crayons, pens, brain teaser puzzles, and word searches.

steps.headline: Pack books and a journal for older children.
steps.description: Have each child pack 1 or 2 books of their choice for the trip. If they have books they need to read for school, this would be a perfect time to read that book. You can also include a diary or journal for your kids who like to write. Have them write 1 or more entry every day about the trip. If you’re travelling during the school year, a travel journal may even be something your child can hand in as homework when they get back.

steps.headline: Add a pre-made craft kit so your child can learn a new skill.
steps.description: Craft stores, art stores, hobby stores, and many online stores sell pre-made kits for a variety of different crafts. These craft kits are typically designed to teach a specific skill, such as knitting or drawing. Purchase one of these pre-made kits for each child so they have something new to learn while travelling. Obviously, you’ll need to be selective about which kit to buy, as they’ll be in a cramped location that may be bumping or jostling around. A soap making kit or even a jewellery making kit is likely not appropriate for the car or plane (but maybe okay at a hotel or a relative's house).

steps.headline: Collect or buy a small-sized binder for each of your children.
steps.description: The binder can be anywhere from 0.5 to 1.5 inches (1.3 to 3.8 cm) wide. Reuse or repurpose an existing binder or purchase a new binder at the dollar store or an office supply store. If you’re able to find a binder with a clear plastic pocket on the front and pockets on the inside, even better (but not necessary). Travel binders could even be useful for teenagers or adults, as you can customize what you put inside.

steps.headline: Personalize the binders for each of your children.
steps.description: Have your children help you personalize their own binders if you want. Print a cover for each binder that has your child’s name on it and maybe the name of the trip you’re taking (e.g., “European Vacation 2020”). If your binder has a clear plastic pocket on the front, simply slide the cover page into the pocket. Otherwise, use tape or glue to attach the cover to the front of the binder. If your kids want to personalize their own binders, have them write their names with a permanent marker or add a variety of stickers they like to the outside.

steps.headline: Add a binder pouch to the front of the binder.
steps.description: Binder pouches are pencil cases that are designed to go inside a binder. They typically have 3 grommet holes where the pouch can be secured within the rings of the binder. Place one that you’ve purchased at the dollar store or office support store inside each binder. Alternatively, if you can’t find a pencil case designed for a binder, you can duct tape a flat pencil case to the inside cover of the binder. The purpose of this step is to ensure the pencil case cannot get separated from the binder.

steps.headline: Fill the binder pouch with appropriate writing instruments.
steps.description: At the very least, include 2 dry erase markers in each pouch and 2 mechanical pencils. If you include pencils, also remember to include an eraser. Include a set of coloured pencils if you plan to include colouring pages within the binder. Include a couple of pens for older children. You’ll also want to include a small washable cloth in each pouch which can be used to wipe away the dry erase marker from the plastic sheets.

steps.headline: Print a variety of travel game templates from your computer.
steps.description: Use an internet browser to search for “travel game templates.” Download the templates that interest you and are appropriate for the ages of your children. You can also make your own travel games using word processing or spreadsheet software if you want. Alternatively, you can purchase a game or puzzle book from the book store or dollar store and cut/tear the pages out.

steps.headline: Put 1 or 2 game templates in a plastic sheet protector.
steps.description: Sheet protectors are designed to go inside binders, as they already have 3 holes for the binder’s rings. Plus, dry erase markers can be wiped off the outside of a sheet protector as it’s made of plastic. Each sheet protector can include 2 games; one facing forward and the other facing backwards. If you’ve included games that can only be played once, you don’t need to put them inside a sheet protector.

steps.headline: Add a map of your trip to the front of each binder.
steps.description: Regardless of the type of trip you’re taking, use an online map program like Google Maps to find and print several maps that show your trip. Make sure to print a map that includes your route on it so your kids can follow along. Mark stops on your map so your kids can determine how long it will be until they reach the next stop. Include a country and/or world map in the binder so your kids can see their starting and ending points on a large scale.
